body: The six cable-television companies that were awarded rights to wire the boroughs outside of Manhattan under an agreement concluded yesterday are variously owned by large communications concerns and small local ventures. Manhattan has been served for more than a decade by Manhattan Cable TV in the southern portion and Teleprompter in the northern
title: LARGE AND SMALL COMPANIES AMONG THE WINNERS OF CABLE CONTRACTS

body: The New York City Commission on Human Rights announced yesterday that it had awarded more than $6,000 to a man who had been discriminated against by his employer because he was not of Hispanic descent. The award, against the Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn, was the first the commission had ever made based ''on the complaint of a white worker
title: PANEL MAKES FIRST AWARD TO WHITE MAN IN BIAS CASE

body: Thomas J. Cuite, the City Council majority leader since 1969, held a slight lead early this morning over a young challenger from Brooklyn for the Democratic nomination in the Council's 30th District. The challenger, Stephen DiBrienza, a 27-year-old district leader, ran a surprisingly strong race against Mr. Cuite, who has represented the district
title: COUNCIL MAJORITY LEADER IN TIGHT RACE

body: In a highly unusual case, lawyers from the New York State Attorney General's office won a court order last night in an effort to reverse a court decision that denies an abortion for a retarded 25-year-old woman with the mental age of a 1 1/2-year-old child. Upon discovering the woman's pregnancy last month, the state with the consent of her
title: STATE SEEKING ABORTION FOR A RETARDED WOMAN

body: Primary elections next Thursday are certain to set the stage for the entry of at least four new members into New York's City Council next year and an increase in the number of black and Hispanic members. The changes will come largely as a result of the Council's disputed redistricting process, which took more than a year and led, because of Federal
title: PRIMARIES TO BRING RISE IN MINORITIES ON COUNCIL

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: Three of the 10 convicts who escaped from a medium-security detention center in Queens late Monday night had been returned to custody by yesterday evening. The first escapee to be returned to custody, 32-year-old Reggie Harris of Manhattan, surrendered to authorities at a church in Harlem. The second escapee, , Roger Tillman, 32, was apprehended in
title: POLICE ARREST 3 WHO HAD FLED QUEENS CENTER

body: Old Stone House Gets Flags at Last In the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, the Old Stone House of Gowanus dates back to 1699. The Dutch Colonial building was a headquarters in the 1777 Battle of Long Island, when the British landed from 400 ships in Gravesend Bay and tried to wipe out General Washington's army. Two companies from Maryland were
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: BAY RIDGE is an enclave of churches, children and quiet streets on t he western edge of Brooklyn, where the view of New York Bay is a lmost as spectacular as the pale blue Verrazano-Narrows Bridge that l ooms above it. Residents of this tightly woven community of 116,000 think of it as a small town. Many of them can walk down their streets and know
title: BAY RIDGE

body: WHEN Philp and Jane Cantelmi purchased the 16-unit building at 427 5 7th Street in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn last June, they k new little about the responsibilities of being landlords. ''Our problem,'' Mrs. Cantelmi said, ''was pure and absolute ignorance.'' Seeking help one day, she ran her finger down the lists of city agencies in the
title: NOVICE LANDLORDS GET HELP UNRAVELING RED TAPE

body: In the space of a few weeks this spring, the Rev. Jody Cross-Hansen graduated from Yale Divinity School, got married and received her first assignment as a pastor. She says with good humor that ''it has been a lot of firsts at once.'' On July 1 she and her husband, Alan, moved into the spacious accommodations provided for the minister a few steps
title: 'A LOT OF FIRSTS AT ONCE' FOR A BROOKLYN MINISTER

body: Two programs to fight arson,credited with success in other parts of New York City but with eld from the Bronx because of rivalry between the Fire and Police Departments, will both be operating in the borough starting today. The Fire Department's Red Cap project, so called because its 50 fire marshals wear red caps to make their presence known, will
title: BRONX IS GETTING 2 NEW PROGRAMS TO FIGHT ARSON

body: After a five-year negotiating seige, the Brooklyn Arsenal Building has fallen to Herbert and Henry Mandel. The Mandels, pere and fils of a family that has been building in New York for four generations, purchased the former World War II armory in Sunset Park from New York State for $700,000 and plan to convert it into back-office and computer space
title: POSTINGS; Brooklyn Conversion; Arsenal Redux

body: THE subject is the ''outer'' boroughs, or the ''other'' boroughs - o r, as Herbert J. Sturz has resolved to call them, the Bronx, B rooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. ''Weren't you shocked the first time you were in Brooklyn and the arrows at the subway were pointing to 'The City'?'' asked Mr. Sturz, chairman of the City Planning Commission. ''It's
title: PLANNERS LOOK TO THE 'OTHER' BOROUGHS

body: They came from the Bronx, Brooklyn, Suffolk County and Bergen County. And each of the 50 participants had one thing in mind - how to set up emergency food programs for the poor. That was the purpose of the Emergency Food Conference, and those who attended said that there was an increasing need for emergency food and that the Government seemed to be
title: VOLUNTARY UNITS CONFER ON PLANS TO FEED HUNGRY

body: To the Editor: Nancy White's article (''Sunset Park Gains in Tight Market,'' Feb. 28) provides a fairly accurate sketch of the area's recent history. The article is also correct in noting the attractiveness of many old homes in the area. Unfortunately, the article fails to seriously mention some of the significant problems facing this neighborhood.
title: Sunset Park Woes

body: A fire in an equipment room at the Prospect Avenue BMT subway station in Brooklyn disrupted service on the RR, B and N lines for an hour and a half just before last evening's rush hour. RR trains were halted between DeKalb Avenue in downtown Brooklyn and 36th Street in Sunset Park. B trains were rerouted over the F line along McDonald Avenue and N
title: CITY BRIEFS; BMT Fire Upsets Evening Service

body: Mr. and Mrs. William Lodge Hale 3d of Portland, Me., and Charleston, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Emery Hale, to Christopher George Chapman, son of Judge Ralph Chapman of Brattleboro, Vt., and the late Hope Severance Chapman. The wedding is planned for May 30 at the Old Parish Methodist Church in Weston, Vt. The
title: Alison Hale To Be Wed

body: Corporations in New York City are being asked to help their employees with child day care in the light of expected ''enormous cuts in the Federal budget'' for publicly supported centers. Joyce M. Black, president of the Day Care Council of New York, said that 72 companies had attended a council conference on alternative programs. The council is
title: CORPORATE AID IS SOUGHT IN LIGHT OF EXPECTED DAY-CARE CUTS
